Description: Sandstone stela of Sety I: this piece is the lower right-hand portion of a stela. An unidentifiable part of a scene in sunk relief is at the top of this fragment, and underneath are nine horizontal lines of incised text, part of which concerns the renewal of a religious festival at Thebes. The left edge of this piece is worn and pitted in places, and there is also some loss in the lower right-hand corner. The uneven bottom edge has been restored in modern times. There are no traces of colour.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: The British Museum, 'British Museum Quarterly' 5 (1930-1), 19; A. W. Shorter, 'Journal of Egyptian Archeology' 19 (1933), 60-1 with translation; K. A. Kitchen, ‘Ramesside inscriptions : translated and annotated Notes and comments; 1, Ramesses I, Sethos I and contemporaries’ (Oxford, 1993), 231 (no. 99); P. Brand, 'The monuments of Seti I : epigraphic, historical, and art historical analysis' (Leiden, 2000), 259.
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1982 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 10. (pl.9)
Condition: Fair (incomplete). The left edge of this piece is worn and pitted in places, and there is also some loss in the lower right-hand corner. The uneven bottom edge has been restored in modern times.
Associated places: Named in inscription: Thebes (historic - Upper Egypt)
